title: Threads in Ring-0 under Win95/98
historical_context: This article was written during a time when Windows 95/98 was prevalent, and it explores undocumented techniques for creating multithreaded viruses in Ring-0, a concept that was relatively new and risky.
target_audience: Hackers, malware developers, and security researchers interested in low-level Windows programming and virus development.
short_summary: The article discusses the creation of multithreaded viruses in Ring-0 on Windows 95/98, detailing methods for using threads as anti-heuristic techniques against antivirus software. It provides practical examples and code snippets for creating both Ring-0 and Ring-3 threads.
summary:
In 'Threads in Ring-0 under Win95/98', Benny from 29A delves into the intricacies of creating multithreaded viruses that operate at the Ring-0 level of Windows 95/98. The article emphasizes the potential of using threads as a means to evade heuristic detection by antivirus programs. By leveraging undocumented methods, the author explains how to create both Ring-0 and Ring-3 threads, highlighting the advantages of each approach in maintaining persistence and avoiding detection. The use of threads in malware is presented as a sophisticated technique that can significantly enhance the stealth and effectiveness of malicious software. 

The article is rich with technical details, including code snippets and explanations of the Windows Virtual Device Driver (VxD) services necessary for thread creation. Benny provides a step-by-step guide on how to implement these techniques, making it a valuable resource for those interested in low-level Windows programming and virus development. The informal tone and personal anecdotes add a unique flavor to the technical content, making it both informative and engaging for the reader.
